Description: Terracotta scaraboid-mould in Nile clay with impression of a circular stud; to cast dome-shaped scaraboids; thick remains of yellow whitish paste inside impression; in orange brown micaceous Nile silt fabric.
Curator's comments: Glazed composition scarabs and scaraboids produced at Naukratis were usually cast and not carved or incised; this technique, highly characteristic of Naukratite productions, allowed a mass-production of these small objects which were mainly intended for export in the whole Mediterranean area and even as far as Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 177-180, fig. 35). Numerous terracotta moulds for scarabs, scaraboids and amulets were discovered at the site (on the various productions from the Scarab Factory see Webb, forthcoming). Dome-shaped scaraboids, or circular plaques, are a standard production at Naukratis. Petrie published one example similar to this piece (Petrie 1886, 37, pl. XXXVIII, 18). Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OI.133) (phase 2)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no.18) (similar cast from such mould)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (on behalf of)
